doc.after: In 1869, when Dmitri Mendeleev published his periodic table, the space under iodine was empty; after Niels Bohr established the physical basis of the classification of chemical elements, it was suggested that the fifth halogen belonged there. Before its officially recognized discovery, it was called "eka-iodine" (from Sanskrit ekaÂ â "one") to imply it was one space under iodine (in the same manner as eka-silicon, eka-boron, and others).[79] Scientists tried to find it in nature; given its rarity, these attempts resulted in several false discoveries.[80]
